raw_text:
'Blog' picked as word of the year
 
 The term "blog" has been chosen as the top word of 2004 by a US dictionary publisher.
 
 Merriam-Webster said "blog" headed the list of most looked-up terms on its site during the last twelve months. During 2004 blogs, or web logs, have become hugely popular and some have started to influence mainstream media. Other words on the Merriam-Webster list were associated with major news events such as the US presidential election or natural disasters that hit the US.
 
 Merriam-Webster defines a blog as: "a Web site that contains an online personal journal with reflections, comments and often hyperlinks". Its list of most looked-up words is drawn up every year and it discounts terms such as swear words, that everyone likes to look up, or those that always cause problems, such as "affect" and "effect".
 
 Merriam-Webster said "blog" was the word that people have asked to be defined or explained most often over the last 12 months. The word will now appear in the 2005 version of Merriam-Webster's printed dictionary. However, the word is already included in some printed versions of the Oxford English Dictionary. A spokesman for the Oxford University Press said that the word was now being put into other dictionaries for children and learners, reflecting its mainstream use. "I think it was the word of last year rather than this year," he said. "Now we're getting words that derive from it such as 'blogosphere' and so on," he said. "But," he added, "it's a pretty recent thing and in the way that this happens these days it's got established very quickly."
 
 Blogs come in many different forms. Many act as news sites for particular groups or subjects, some are written from a particular political slant and others are simply lists of interesting sites. Other terms in the top 10 were related to natural disasters that have struck the US, such as "hurricane" or were to do with the US election. Words such as "incumbent", "electoral" and "partisan" reflected the scale of interest in the vote. Blogs also proved very useful to both sides in the US election battle because many pundits who maintain their own journals were able to air opinions that would never appear in more mainstream media. Speculation that President Bush was getting help during debates via a listening device was first aired on web logs. Online journals also raised doubts about documents used by US television news organisation CBS in a story about President Bush's war record. The immediacy of many blogs also helped some wield influence over topics that made it in to national press.
 
 This is despite the fact that the number of people reading even the most influential blogs is tiny. Statistics by web influence ranking firm HitWise reveal that the most popular political blog racks up only 0.0051% of all net visits per day. One of the reasons that blogs and regularly updated online journals have become popular is because the software used to put them together make it very easy for people to air their views online. According to blog analysis firm Technorati the number of blogs in existence, the blogosphere, has doubled every five and a half months for the last 18 months. Technorati now estimates that the number of blogs in existence has exceeded 4.8 million. Some speculate that less than a quarter of this number are regularly maintained. According to US research firm Pew Internet & American Life a blog is created every 5.8 seconds. Another trend this year has been the increasing numbers of weblogs that detail the daily lives of many ordinary workers in jobs that few people know much about. In many repressive regimes and developing nations, blogs have been embraced by millions of people keen to give their plight a voice.
llama3.2:1b: The term "blog" was chosen as the US dictionary publisher's word of 2004. Blogs refer to online personal journals with reflections, comments, and hyperlinks, often written from various perspectives. They became popular in 2004 and started influencing mainstream media during this time. Other words on the list were associated with major news events such as elections or natural disasters in the US. The Merriam-Webster dictionary defines a blog as "a Web site that contains an online personal journal."
llama3.2:3b: The term "blog" was chosen as the top word of 2004 by Merriam-Webster, reflecting its growing popularity in mainstream media. A blog is defined as an online personal journal with reflections and comments. The word was frequently looked up and will be included in the 2005 printed dictionary, along with terms related to major news events such as natural disasters and the US presidential election. Blogs have become influential due to their ease of use, immediacy, and ability to air opinions that may not appear in mainstream media.
gemma2:2b: The word "blog" was chosen as 2004's word of the year by Merriam-Webster based on its highest popularity in online searches over the past twelve months.  Blogs are personal websites that contain reflections, comments and often hyperlinks, and they gained mainstream prominence due to their influence in news events, elections, and natural disasters. Blogs' ability to provide real-time opinions and information has made them a tool for political commentary and investigative journalism. While they remain popular, the number of people reading even influential blogs is small. The rise of blogs also reflects an easy creation process through readily available software, leading to rapid growth in the blogosphere with millions of blogs created daily.
qwen2.5:0.5b: "Blog," the most popular word of 2004 according to Merriam-Webster, is now included in some printed versions of Oxford English Dictionary for children and learners. The word has also made its way into other dictionaries such as the online journals "The Guardian" and "The Times".
qwen2.5:1.5b: The term "blog" was chosen as Word of the Year by Merriam-Webster based on its popularity during 2004. It refers to an online personal journal that often includes hyperlinks and is used for various purposes such as news sites, political slants, lists of interesting sites, or speculation about presidential election outcomes. Blogging has become very popular due to the ease with which people can share their views on websites. The term was included in both Merriam-Webster's printed dictionary and some versions of the Oxford English Dictionary. However, it is still new enough that it will continue to be added to other dictionaries as it becomes more mainstream.
qwen2.5:3b: 'Blog' was chosen as the top word of 2004 by Merriam-Webster due to its high usage on the publisher's site during the previous year. Blogs became hugely popular and influenced mainstream media in 2004, with other words related to major events like natural disasters or US presidential election also appearing on their list. According to Merriam-Webster, blogs are defined as online personal journals that include comments and hyperlinks. The term 'blog' has been included in various dictionaries since its creation. Blogs come in different forms, serving as news sites, expressing political views, or simply listing interesting links. In 2004, other top terms were associated with natural disasters affecting the US and electoral events. Blogs proved useful during the US election by allowing pundits to share opinions on social media platforms, sometimes influencing mainstream media coverage. Despite low readership numbers, blogs have become popular due to user-friendly software that enables easy sharing of personal views online. The number of existing blogs has been doubling every five and a half months for nearly two years, with estimates suggesting over 4.8 million blogs exist worldwide. Some believe less than a quarter are regularly maintained, while many in oppressive or developing nations use blogs to voice their concerns.

2. During 2004 blogs, or web logs, have become hugely popular.
3. Other words on the Merriam-Webster list were associated with major news events such as the US presidential election or natural disasters that hit the US.
4. Words related to natural disasters and political sites (like 'hurricane' and 'incumbent') are also included.
5. The term "blogs" was used for a variety of purposes, from news sites to writing personal opinions.
6. The use of software to create online journals has made blogging an easy process.
7. According to HitWise, the blogosphere has doubled every five and a half months for the last 18 months. The number of blogs in existence is increasing significantly.
8. According to Technorati, more than 4.8 million weblogs exist in existence. 
9. There have been approximately 5.8 seconds (approximately one minute per second) between blog creation, indicating an increase in the frequency of blogging online. 

The text preserves all these key points and provides a detailed explanation of what each term means.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
In 2004, Merriam-Webster designated "blog" as the top word of the year due to its rapid popularity. Blogs, or web logs, became influential in mainstream media and were associated with various topics, including major news events like the US presidential election and natural disasters. The term is defined by Merriam-Webster as an online personal journal containing reflections and comments. Despite their influence, blogs' readership remains minimal—approximately 0.0051% of all net visits per day for the most popular political blog.

Blogs serve diverse purposes, acting as news sites for specific groups, expressing political views, or sharing interesting links. They have enabled individuals to voice opinions previously unseen in mainstream media. For instance, blogs first raised doubts about President Bush's debate performance and CBS's war record documentation. Additionally, they have played a significant role in amplifying the voices of ordinary workers worldwide, particularly in repressive regimes and developing nations.

The blogosphere has doubled every five-and-a-half months for the past 18 months, according to Technorati estimates, with over 4.8 million existing blogs. The Pew Internet & American Life research firm reports that a blog is created approximately every 5.8 seconds. This rapid growth underscores blogs' growing significance in shaping public discourse and providing alternative perspectives on current events.
